conclusion: The setup involves a semi-cylindrical transparent brick with refractive index n and radius r, a laser beam initially at point A, and the beam moves downward along the AC diameter at a constant speed V.
We need to find when light first emerges from the curved surface ABC.
Snell's law: n1 sin(theta1) = n2 sin(theta2).
For light to exit from the curved surface, it must hit the surface at an angle less than the critical angle.
Critical angle formula: sin(theta_c) = 1/n (when going from material to air).
Point O is the center of the semi-circle, the beam enters perpendicular to the flat surface at some point D between A and C, and the beam then travels through the brick at angle theta to the normal.
R represents the radius of the semi-circle.
For light to emerge from the curved surface, the angle of incidence (inside the material) must be less than the critical angle: sin(theta) < 1/n.
When the beam enters at point D (at distance y from O), it makes an angle theta with the normal inside the material. From the diagram, sin(theta) = y/r.
Light will start to emerge when sin(theta) = 1/n. Substituting our relationship: y/r = 1/n, therefore y = r/n.
Initially, the beam is at point A, which is at position y = r from O. The beam needs to travel distance (r - r/n) to reach the critical position.
Given uniform speed V, the time taken is t = (r - r/n)/V = r(1 - 1/n)/V = r(n-1)/(nV).
The moment when light first emerges from the arc surface ABC is t = r(n-1)/(nV).
